questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever is? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is the drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever due to its efficacy in reducing inflammation and managing symptoms like arthritis and carditis, which are common in rheumatic fever. The other listed drugs are not used for this condition and are more specific to heart diseases and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: This medication is a cardiac glycoside, typically used in heart failure and certain arrhythmias. It is not used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of various cardiac arrhythmias. It is not indicated for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic, often used in conditions like heart failure and hypertension. It is not a treatment for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug and is commonly used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever, particularly for its anti-inflammatory effects in managing arthritis and carditis associated with rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.

 

Larva currens â€“ Strongyloides stercolaris

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercolaris: Incorrect, although Strongyloides stercolaris can cause skin symptoms (known as larva currens) due to the rapid migration of larvae, it is not the most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option B. Toxocara canis: Incorrect, this organism causes toxocariasis or visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting organs and causing systemic symptoms, rather than the localized skin manifestations seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: Incorrect, this is a human hookworm that primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms upon infection, not cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: What is the postmortem sign in which a gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Robert‘s sign

 

Robert sign refers to the presence of a gas shadow within the heart or the greater vessels, in cases of fetal death in utero. It is a rare sign caused by postmortem blood degeneration, usually seen 1-2 days after death; and may be seen as early as 12 hours.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Spalding sign – overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by collapse of the fetal brain.

 

Option C. Ball sign - hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

 

Option D. Halo sign - increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault.

 

Educational objective

 

Roberts sign is characterized by the presence of gas shadows in the heart or great vessels of a fetus, indicating intrauterine demise and typically appearing 1-2 days postmortem.

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

 

If the hydrostatic pressure of the capillaries or the oncotic pressure of the Bowman's capsule decreases, filtration will decrease. If the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillary increases or if the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's capsule increases, GFR will decrease as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the net filtration pressure, which depends on various pressures within the glomerulus and Bowman's capsule:

 

Option A. Increased Renal Blood Flow: This increases GFR as more blood flow leads to higher filtration.

 

Option B. Increased Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure: This also increases GFR because higher pressure in the glomerulus drives more filtrate into Bowman's capsule.

 

Option D. Decreased Glomerular Oncotic Pressure: This increases GFR because lower protein concentration in the glomerulus reduces the opposing force to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure reduces net filtration pressure (NFP) and decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases filtration pressure and GFR.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 districts to measure the mean blood pressure. Health workers visited each house of the 3 districts. Identify the epidemiological study design. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross sectional study.

 

A cross-sectional study involves collecting data at a single point in time from a population or a representative subset to assess the prevalence of outcomes or characteristics, such as mean blood pressure. In this case, health workers visited each house in the three districts at the same time to measure blood pressure, making it a cross-sectional study. This type of study is also known as a "snapshot study" or "prevalence study" because it provides a picture of the population's health status at one point in time, allowing the calculation of prevalence rates for conditions like hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case control study: This design involves comparing individuals with a particular condition (cases) to those without it (controls) and looking retrospectively to identify exposures. Since the study described is not retrospective and does not involve comparing cases to controls, it is not a case control study.

 

Option C. Cohort study: A cohort study follows a group of individuals over time to see how certain exposures affect outcomes. The study in question does not follow participants over time but rather assesses them at one point in time, ruling out the cohort study design.

 

Option D. Ecological study: An ecological study looks at data at the group or population level rather than individual level, often using existing data. The study described involves direct data collection from individuals, making it unsuitable as an ecological study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cross-sectional study collects data from a population at one point in time, often used to determine the prevalence of a condition like hypertension.

questions.text: In a patient with thyroid malignancy, serum calcitonin was found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid, which produce the hormone calcitonin. Elevated serum calcitonin is a characteristic marker for MTC. In addition to calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can also be elevated in MTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because follicular thyroid carcinoma typically does not elevate calcitonin. Instead, it may show elevated serum thyroglobulin.

 

Option B. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: This is incorrect because papillary thyroid carcinoma is associated with elevated serum thyroglobulin, not calcitonin.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: This is incorrect as anaplastic carcinoma is an aggressive form of thyroid cancer that does not produce calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is the thyroid cancer associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels, distinguishing it from other types of thyroid malignancies.

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Right atrium
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation

 

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

 

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. While the right atrium receives blood from the inferior vena cava, it also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, leading to a mixture that has a lower oxygen concentration than the incoming blood from the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava: Incorrect. The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from the head and upper limbs of the fetus, thus having a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Option D. Ascending aorta: Incorrect. Although the ascending aorta in the fetus does carry oxygenated blood, the highest concentration of oxygen is found in the blood before it reaches the heart, specifically in the inferior vena cava due to the direct input from the umbilical vein through the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava due to its receipt of oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein, which has directly exchanged gases in the placenta. This setup is crucial for delivering a sufficient oxygen supply to the developing fetus.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl serine

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

 

Explanation

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline (DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant (surfactant is a surface-active agent, secreted by type II alveolar epithelial cells) It is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions.
  • The surfactant decreases the surface tension in the alveoli 2- to 10-fold, which normally plays a major role in preventing alveolar collapse.
  • However, in a number of conditions, such as in hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome), which often occurs in newborn premature babies, the quantity of surfactant secreted by the alveoli is so greatly depressed that the surface tension of the alveolar fluid becomes several times normal. This causes a serious tendency for the lungs of these babies to collapse or to become filled with fluid.
  • Clinical relevance - Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio –lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidyl serine: Incorrect. While phosphatidyl serine is a component of cell membranes and plays roles in signaling, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not specifically linked to respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylethanolamine: Incorrect. Similar to phosphatidyl serine, phosphatidylethanolamine is a component of cell membranes and is involved in cellular processes but does not play a direct role in reducing alveolar surface tension or preventing respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylinositol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylinositol is involved in cellular signaling pathways and membrane structure but is not a significant component of pulmonary surfactant related to respiratory function or the pathology of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and is the primary component deficient in respiratory distress syndrome, particularly in premature infants. This deficiency underscores the importance of surfactant therapy in the management of this condition.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe â€“ NR (NR â€“ Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/mÂ² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/mÂ²), hypoventilation (PaCO2 >45 mmHg), and lack of significant underlying lung disease. The ABG findings showing hypercapnia (high PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) in the awake state are indicative of OHS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Occurs during sleep, not necessarily presenting with hypercapnia in the awake state.
 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep without the obesity-related hypoventilation.
 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Does not typically present with ABG abnormalities or obesity hypoventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: A patientâ€™s higher mental functions were being assessed by a psychiatrist. He was asked to serially subtract 7 from 100. Which mental function is being assessed? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concentration

 

Serial Seven Subtraction Test is used to assess concentration and immediate memory.

 

Concentration is the ability to sustain attention for a longer duration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Judgement: Incorrect, as judgement involves decision-making and reasoning about complex matters, which is not directly assessed by simple arithmetic tasks.

 

Option C. Orientation: Incorrect, orientation refers to awareness of time, place, and person, which is not relevant to the serial subtraction task.

 

Option D. Attention: Incorrect, although attention is required for this task, the specific function being tested is concentration, which is a sustained form of attention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concentration, the ability to maintain attention on a task over a period of time, is assessed through the Serial Seven Subtraction Test in mental function evaluations.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension. He has a history of renal stones and has experienced a few episodes of renal colic. Which diuretic is the most appropriate to use? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that decreases calcium excretion in the urine by promoting calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. This mechanism reduces the amount of calcium that is excreted into the urine, which lowers the risk of renal stone formation. Although thiazides can cause hypercalcemia by increasing calcium levels in the blood, they are beneficial in patients with a history of renal stones because they reduce urinary calcium levels, thereby decreasing the likelihood of stone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine by inhibiting calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This can lead to increased calcium in the urine, which raises the risk of renal stone formation, making it less appropriate for patients with a history of renal stones.

 

Option C. Ethacrynic acid: Similar to furosemide, ethacrynic acid is a loop diuretic that increases calcium excretion in the urine. Its use can also increase the risk of renal stones and is not the best choice for patients with a history of nephrolithiasis.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works primarily by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron, leading to the retention of potassium and excretion of sodium. It does not have a significant impact on calcium excretion and is not indicated for reducing the risk of renal stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is the preferred diuretic in patients with a history of renal stones because it reduces urinary calcium excretion, thereby decreasing the risk of stone formation.

questions.text: Under MTP Act of India, for cases of MTP after 24 weeks POG, there has to be a Medical board to advise. It comprises of all except: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Legal advisor


Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, a Medical Board must be constituted for termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks, specifically in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. This board plays a crucial role in evaluating the circumstances and approving the procedure when necessary. The Medical Board is required to have specific members to provide expert medical advice, including:

 

  1. An Obstetrician-Gynaecologist who provides expertise on maternal and fetal health.
  2. A Radiologist who is crucial for diagnosing fetal anomalies through imaging.
  3. A Paediatrician who offers insights into the potential viability and health of the fetus.
  4. Members nominated by state government in official Gazette

 

These experts collectively evaluate the condition to ensure a medically sound decision. However, the board does not include a legal advisor, as their role is primarily medical, focusing on the health aspects rather than legal counsel.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Medical Board for MTP cases beyond 24 weeks includes an Obstetrician-Gynaecologist, Radiologist, and Paediatrician but does not include a legal advisor.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severeâ€™? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

Haemophilia B is characterized by a deficiency in factor IX. The treatment for haemophilia B focuses on supplementing the deficient factor IX. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an excellent source of factor IX and is therefore useful in treating haemophilia B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Incorrect. Cryoprecipitate is rich in factor VIII and is primarily used for treating haemophilia A, not haemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Incorrect. Recombinant factor VIII is used to treat haemophilia A, which is a deficiency in factor VIII, not factor IX.

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Incorrect. Although cryo poor plasma can still contain some factor IX, it is not the best choice compared to fresh frozen plasma. Cryo poor plasma is more commonly used for treating thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas disease.

 

It is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder, causing:

 

  • Easy bruising
  • Hemarthroses
  • Prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery

 

For the treatment of haemophilia B, fresh frozen plasma is an effective source of factor IX. Recombinant factor IX would be the best treatment option if available.

choices.text: Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers
It can be used for resistant malaria
It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid
It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pretomanid? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

 

Explanation: 


Pretomanid is approved as part of the BPaL (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) regime for treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) and pre-XDR TB in India. This combination therapy represents a significant advancement in treating highly resistant forms of tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers: Incorrect. Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, not CYP2C9, and is contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

 

Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria: Incorrect. Pretomanid is specifically approved for tuberculosis treatment, not malaria.

 

Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species: Incorrect. Pretomanid acts by releasing reactive nitrogen species (not oxygen), which inhibit mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 


Pretomanid is part of the BPaL regimen (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) approved for treating XDR-TB and pre-XDR TB, and works through the release of reactive nitrogen species to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.

 

New Drugs:

 

  1. Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation
  2. Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation
  3. Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Test for ANCA


The clinical presentation of ENT involvement, lung nodules with cavitations, and renal failure suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) test is a useful diagnostic tool for GPA.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Biopsy to show granulomas is useful but more invasive.

 

Option C. AFB staining of sputum is for TB, not GPA.

 

Option D. BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage):  is not specific for diagnosing GPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected GPA, the ANCA test is the most useful initial investigation.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

 

Explanation

 

PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Countercurrent system has two divisions:

 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.

 

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

 

  1. Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.

 

Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.

 

Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and â€˜strippingâ€™ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-Î²-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is disposed in the yellow bag? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood bag

 

Blood bag is disposed in the yellow bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gloves: Red bag.

 


Option C.  Sharps: White container.

 

Option D. Urine bags: Red bag.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date canâ€™t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The classification shown is for? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Pelvic organ prolapse


The classification shown in the image is the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system, which is used to classify pelvic organ prolapse.

 

Pelvic organ prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs, including the uterus, bladder, and rectum, into or outside of the vaginal canal. The POP-Q system is a standardized method that provides detailed measurements of the degree and location of prolapse using specific points and measurements.

 

The reference point in this classification is the hymen, and the system documents anterior wall descent, posterior wall descent, and other prolapse details through a 3x3 grid with six specific points (Aa, Ba, C, Ap, Bp, and D) and three measurements (genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length). This detailed system allows for accurate assessment and comparison of prolapse severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer:  is incorrect because cervical cancer staging does not use the POP-Q system. Instead, cervical cancer staging is typically done using FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) criteria, which focus on tumor size and spread rather than anatomical descent.

 

Option C. Vulvar cancer: is incorrect. Vulvar cancer staging is also not related to pelvic organ prolapse or the POP-Q classification. It typically involves examining tumor size and invasion depth.

 

Option D. Uterine anomalies: is incorrect because uterine anomalies refer to congenital abnormalities of uterine structure and do not involve prolapse quantification. These are usually diagnosed with imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, not classified with a system like POP-Q.

 

Educational Objective:


The POP-Q system is a specific and standardized classification method used to quantify and describe the extent of pelvic organ prolapse using detailed anatomical measurements. The hymen is the reference point for this classification.

questions.text: A 60-year-old with lower backache had low hemoglobin, increased creatinine and multiple osteolytic lesions on radiograph. His serum electrophoresis revealed normal albumin but disproportionately high globulin. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple myeloma

 

The clinical picture presented is suggestive of anemia, renal dysfunction and bony lytic lesions with increased production of globulin levels suggestive of monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells and meeting the CRAB criteria of multiple myeloma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prostate cancer: Prostate cancer can present with bone pain due to metastasis, but it typically causes sclerotic (rather than osteolytic) bone lesions and does not cause the marked increase in globulin levels seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Pott's spine: This refers to tuberculosis of the spine and can present with back pain and osteolytic lesions, but it is not associated with increased globulin levels or the hematological findings seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis can cause bone pain and fractures but does not cause anemia, renal dysfunction, or increased globulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, renal dysfunction, osteolytic bone lesions, and a high globulin level due to monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with seizures and neck rigidity. The CSF examination shows the presence of organisms on India ink and a diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. Which of the following anti-fungal drug is used for initial treatment of this meningitis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liposomal amphotericin

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The initial treatment aims to rapidly reduce the fungal burden in the central nervous system (CNS).

 

  • Liposomal Amphotericin B: This is the drug of choice for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. Liposomal formulations of amphotericin B are preferred because they are less nephrotoxic and have a better safety profile compared to conventional amphotericin B. Amphotericin B works by binding to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is typically used for maintenance therapy after the initial reduction of fungal burden by amphotericin B and flucytosine. High-dose fluconazole is not as effective as liposomal amphotericin B for initial treatment.

 

Option C. Fluconazole + 5 Flucytosine: This combination can be used, but the standard initial treatment for cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole is more commonly used for maintenance therapy after the initial phase.

 

Option D. Voriconazole: Voriconazole is used primarily for aspergillosis and some other fungal infections but is not the first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS, liposomal amphotericin B is the preferred drug due to its efficacy in rapidly reducing the fungal burden in the CNS and its better safety profile compared to conventional amphotericin B. Fluconazole is used for maintenance therapy following the initial treatment phase.

questions.text: A child has presented with a birth defect as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Craniorachischisis with anencephaly


Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect that involves both the brain and spinal cord. It is a combination of anencephaly and spina bifida, where there is a failure of closure of the entire length of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the brain (anencephaly) and an open spinal cord (rachischisis). The image provided shows the characteristic features of this condition, including the exposed brain and spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: Anencephaly is considered an anterior neuropore defect. During embryonic development, the neural tube forms, and this process involves the closure of two openings known as neuroporesâ€”one at the anterior (head) end and one at the posterior (tail) end. Anencephaly occurs when there is a failure of the closure of the anterior neuropore, leading to incomplete development of the brain and skull.

 

 

Option C. Spina bifida: Neural tube defect with the best prognosis is spina bifida.

 

Option D. Anencephaly with meningocele: Anencephaly with meningocele is a neural tube defect with the following image

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect involving both the brain and spinal cord, with the worst prognosis among neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta, in contrast, has the best prognosis among these conditions.

questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Designated Microscopy Centre 

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria. The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: This option is higher up in the hierarchy than the DMC. It is responsible for the supervision and monitoring of TB control activities within the district, making it central but not the most peripheral.
 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory:  The IRL provides quality assurance for TB diagnosis and conducts drug susceptibility testing. It is a specialized facility that supports the network by confirming diagnoses and resistance patterns, placed higher in the organizational hierarchy than DMCs.
 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit:  While the Tuberculosis Unit is responsible for providing treatment and care to TB patients, it is not as peripheral as the DMC. The TU operates within a more integrated role in patient management and care continuum than the DMC, which is strictly focused on initial diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains a foundational component in the RNTCP for its role in accessible, community-level TB diagnosis and initial management. Its position as the most peripheral center in the hierarchy underscores its critical function in early TB detection and intervention.

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the â€˜Rule of Nineâ€™, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitotâ€™s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OClâ»): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Clâ»): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES Ã  DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl â†’ HCI + HOCI HOCI â†’ H + OCI

questions.text: Inhibin is responsible for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibition of FSH secretion

 

Inhibin is a hormone released from the gonads (testes in males and ovaries in females) that primarily functions to inhibit the secretion of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland. The role of inhibin is to provide negative feedback to the pituitary to regulate the production and release of FSH, ensuring that the levels of this hormone are kept in balance for proper reproductive function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibition of prolactin: Inhibin does not affect prolactin secretion. Prolactin regulation is primarily controlled by prolactin-inhibiting hormone (dopamine) and prolactin-releasing factors.

 

Option C. Stimulation of FSH secretion: Inhibin inhibits rather than stimulates the secretion of FSH.

 

Option D. Stimulation of prolactin: Inhibin does not stimulate prolactin secretion. It specifically targets FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin is responsible for inhibiting the secretion of FSH from the anterior pituitary gland, serving as a critical regulator in the reproductive hormone feedback system.
